column3: Won't this detect the no-op obfuscation too? That wouldn't be a good idea...\n
@MarcoFalke luke-jr is right you need to also check for the null obfuscation key\n
@pstratem Why would someone write a null obfuscation key?\n
@MarcoFalke it's a quirk of how the obfuscation code works, it's XOR so a null obfuscation key is the same as no obfuscation key\n
Do we ever _write_ a null key? (as opposed to treating no key as null)\n
@pstratem But it  is never **written** to the db. This would be like saying I obfuscate every of my GitHub messages with the null obfuscation key. (It's redundant and not needed)\n

Concept ACK but doubting if this or #6919 makes more sense. \nSure, backporting the whole thing involves somewhat more code but it seemed more useful than introducing a little bit less of code to just warn.\n

@laanwj This can be cherry-picked to 0.10 without conflicts as well. As this issue seems popular ( https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/7258#issuecomment-167353533 ) we need either #7259 (this) or #6919, imo.\n\nKeep in mind you can rebase #6919 simply on a commit which reverts #7259 (this), in case you want to reopen after #7259 (this) got merged. ("'Don't Let Perfect Be The Enemy Of Good'")

Yeah, this is fine for 0.11. It's easier to test that it rejects a database than to test whether it works.

Would be nice to have at least one tested ACK, though.
